ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

Column No : 1102

MEDISHIELD

(Number of lapsed cases)

     1.  Mr Terry Lee asked the Minister for Health (a) over the last three years, what is the trend of MediShield cases which have lapsed because an individual had insufficient Medisave or exhausted his Medisave; (b) what is the forecast of the number of MediShield cases which may lapse in 2010; (c) whether his Ministry has plans to prevent such lapsed cases and; (d) whether he will consider offering retirees some alternative form of basic medical coverage. 

     The Minister for Health (Mr Khaw Boon Wan):  Last year, less than 1% of MediShield policies lapsed due to insufficient Medisave savings.  As it will not be in the interest of the policyholders to allow their MediShield to lapse, MOH and CPF Board go to some length to help the policyholders avoid such an outcome and to restore their MediShield coverage, if possible.

 

     First, CPF members will receive prior alerts and get up to three notification letters at various intervals. Second, we give members a two-month grace period to top up their Medisave to enjoy uninterrupted MediShield coverage. Third, we include a reminder in the members’ annual CPF statements. Fourth, we exercise some flexibility to allow members whose MediShield policies have lapsed to be covered under MediShield again, provided their health status has not changed and they start making regular contributions to Medisave.  And many have indeed rejoined MediShield under such an arrangement.

 

     Sir, as I stressed yesterday, Singaporeans should stay within MediShield and must not allow their coverage to lapse or they will regret it in future.  For those who have exhausted their Medisave, their working family members should help them pay their MediShield premiums.  Their Medisave can be used for this purpose.

     Mr Terry Lee (Nominated Member):   Sir, supplementary question.  Would the Minister consider helping policyholders who are 65 years and above with discounted premiums?

     Mr Khaw Boon Wan:  Sir, in formulating our insurance policy – and MediShield included – we have tried to avoid inter-generational cross subsidy.  It does not work in the long term, meaning the young subsidises the old, because we know the population pyramid will change with age.  When the pyramid is fat at the bottom, it is easy because there are many young people to support the old.  But at some stage, the pyramid becomes more like a diamond which is what countries in the West are facing today.  They introduced such policies 50 years ago – which then sounded very gentle and rational – but they are now finding great difficulty in continuing.  What we have done instead is to encourage early subscription and then, allow discounts for loyalty, ie, under a loyalty programme.  So the longer you stay, you get greater discounts below what your age group premium ought to be actuarially.  I think that is the correct way, going forward. 

     Assoc. Prof. Paulin Tay Straughan (Nominated Member): Thank you, Mr Speaker.  I have two supplementary questions for Minister.  The first concerns older Singaporeans.  I am wondering if MediShield is sufficient for chronic ailments.  This is the group that is caught in the gap because they are very likely not to be covered by private insurance.  What plans does Minister have to augment their healthcare bills?  My second supplementary question addresses the middle-aged group, people whom we are now encouraging to go for early health screening so that we can detect ailments at an earlier stage.  And yet, contradictory to that, once you have a pre-existing illness, private insurers fail to cover you.  So it seems we are sending a lot of people into the lion's den and then they will be without coverage for a long period of time.  May I have the Minister's comments?

     Mr Khaw Boon Wan:   Sir, we have designed MediShield to look after acute hospitalisation, treatments that are generally provided in acute hospitals.  The MediShield coverage, premiums and payouts accommodate all the age groups.  It is quite robust.  It does not mean that if you are elderly, your MediShield may run out or prove inadequate, that is not the case.  You have heard in the Prime Minister's National Day Rally speech over the weekend about step-down healthcare, outside of acute hospitals.  This is a new and growing area as our population ages.  We think that their needs can be adequately taken care of outside of acute hospitals – in fact it would be cheaper for the patients and their families as well.  This refers to healthcare in nursing homes, and also community hospitals which the Prime Minister spoke about at great length.

 

     Currently, MediShield covers community hospitals.  We are now studying how we can also fund long-term care outside of acute and community hospitals, and that includes home nursing as well.  So this is a new topic that my Ministry is placing great emphasis on and something that we can continue to discuss over the next few months.  I am sure it will be an area of attention in next year's Budget Debate for the Ministry for Health.

 

     The Member also asked about middle-aged patients who, after screening, discover something that private insurance may not pay for.  It does not work that way because if it does, it would completely discourage medical screening. Who will then go for medical screening, in order to have ailments picked up and then be excluded from insurance coverage?  But what insurance does – logically and globally – is to exclude pre-existing illnesses.  In other words, if you already had something which was there for many years before you subscribed to your insurance policy, the insurers would then exclude that.  Those are exceptions rather than the norm.  For most people, so long as you subscribe early to MediShield, the insurance will have to cover the illnesses that crop up, eg, cancer, that you get because of ageing.  The insurance will have to cover these, whether it is MediShield run by CPF Board or Integrated Shields run by private insurers.  I explained yesterday the reason why insurers have to exclude pre-existing illnesses.  If everybody waited until they fell ill to subscribe to insurance policies, it would be unfair to those of us who have been subscribing for years.

     Dr Lam Pin Min (Ang Mo Kio):   I would like to ask the Minister this.  Currently, the Medisave maximum allowable usage for acute hospitalisation is $450 for daily hospital charges.  And for community hospitals, it is just $150 per day.  This disparity may have encouraged patients to stay put in the acute hospitals rather than transfer to community hospitals.  Will the Ministry review this criterion to encourage more elderly sick or those with chronic diseases to transfer to community hospitals instead?

     Mr Khaw Boon Wan:  As part of the review on community hospital care, we are looking at how to fund this and ensure right-siting so that we do not have an incentive system that is warped, that ends up with patients going to a more expensive place because of the funding structure.  We would certainly review how we subvent community hospitals, what is the withdrawal limit out of Medisave and also what is the insurance coverage.  We will take a look at whether $150 daily limit is adequate.  We had set a differential claim limit because the cost of care is indeed lower, and so the claim limit is lower (than for acute hospital).  If we set it too high, it may encourage providers to over price, knowing that the bill will be paid out of Medisave.  I am not saying that our community hospitals do that.  Many of them are run by religious charities and they do not do such things.  But then again, things may happen in an unpredictable way and we need to guard against that.

     Mdm Halimah Yacob (Jurong):  I would like to ask the Minister whether his Ministry can consider extending MediShield coverage to people suffering from mental illnesses because the cost of treating mental illnesses has increased for families and individuals.  Such coverage would indeed be necessary.

     Mr Khaw Boon Wan:   I am sympathetic towards insurance, not just MediShield, covering mental illnesses.  Today, the private MediShield schemes – some of them – do make that provision.  Of course, you would have to pay higher premiums.  I am holding back purely because we would need more money in order to cover this new benefit which requires more payout.  And this is not the time to talk about increasing premiums.

Column No : 1107

MEDISHIELD

(Coverage of big hospital bills)

     2.  Mdm Halimah Yacob asked the Minister for Health (a) whether he can give an update on the progress made in the coverage of big hospital bills up to 80% after the last MediShield review; and (b) whether any persons had dropped out of the scheme because they could not afford the higher premiums.

     Mr Khaw Boon Wan:   Sir, we adjusted the MediShield payouts in December last year – nine months ago.  I am not quite ready yet to discuss the full impact of the changes.  However, the preliminary data are positive.  For example, the MediShield payouts for large hospital bills have gone up from an average of $9,000 per bill to $10,600.  What this means is that such patients would have saved hundreds of dollars per hospitalisation episode.  As for the MediShield lapsed rate, I spoke about it just awhile ago.  Less than 1% of MediShield members have seen their coverage lapse due to insufficient Medisave money.  Among them, how many dropped out because of increased premiums?  As the premium increases are less than a dollar a month, I think the number is likely to be very small, but I do not have such a number.

     Mdm Halimah Yacob:  I would like to ask the Minister whether hospitals have seen a reduction in the number of patients who are not able to pay for big hospital bills because the payout has now been increased.  Secondly, I would like to ask if the Minister could give us an estimate of the state of health of our MediShield funds now that the premiums have increased but payouts have also increased.

     Mr Khaw Boon Wan: Generally, public hospitals do not have a major default problem of arrears whereby patients cannot pay, whether for big bills or small bills.  A lot actually depends on the family financial situation.  We do have some bad debts which we have to write off periodically, but offhand, I cannot recall the rate.  These are manageable.  We need to understand why we are in such a situation.  It is due to Medisave which we put in place 20 years ago.  Can you imagine Singapore without Medisave?  I think affordability of hospital bills would then have been a major problem.  It is precisely because we have enforced savings and rational withdrawal rules, that we are able to afford increasingly high standards of healthcare which inevitably come with high costs.  And the general population, including the lower income group, can afford it.  I would say that for acute hospitals, we are in a reasonably satisfactory situation.  My job in the last two to three years has been focused on long-term care, care outside of acute hospitals.  I am not saying that acute hospitals are perfect.  There are still gaps here and there, and we are trying to fix them as we go along.  But the bigger gap now is in care outside of acute hospitals, or what the Prime Minister described as step-down care.  This is an area that we will be focusing on, and that includes community hospitals, home nursing, as well as in the community – GPs and so on.

 


     As to what is the financial position of MediShield, it was heading towards insolvency prior to 2005, and the reason was what we discussed yesterday, ie, cherry picking, which Prof. Straughan mentioned as a possible phenomenon.  We have fixed that.  We have now won back all the "cherries".  The risk pool of MediShield has now been restored, and we have been able to preserve the financial solvency of MediShield.  Offhand, I do not have the data, but it is healthy.  But like all things, because of escalation in costs and inflation, it requires constant nursing and adjustments – not every year, but every few years or so.

Column No : 1109

CELL-SHARING ARRANGEMENTS FOR PRISON INMATES

     3.  Dr Lam Pin Min asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Home Affairs (a) what is the incidence of prison abuse by cellmates and law enforcement personnel over the last five years; and (b) what measures have been put in place to minimise such occurrences in the prison.

 

    

     4.  Mr Christopher de Souza asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Home Affairs (a) if there are any plans to improve supervision at our prisons to reduce the incidents of violence and abuse by inmates against fellow inmates; and (b) whether the Ministry will consider inviting experienced external parties such as District Judges to provide advice on how to make the disciplinary process against prisoners more transparent and effective in lowering incidences of inmate abuse.

     5.  Ms Sylvia Lim asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Home Affairs (a) what criteria are used to decide cell-sharing arrangements for prison inmates; (b) how the three Changi Prison inmates convicted in July 2009 were able to inflict serious injury on their cellmate for over a week before it was discovered; and (c) whether the prison authorities are addressing any gaps in prisoner management arising from this incident. 

 

 

     The Senior Minister of State for Home Affairs (Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee) (for the Minister for Home Affairs): Sir, may I take Question Nos. 3, 4 and 5 together as they are related?  

     Mr Speaker:  Yes.

     Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee:   Sir, let me state upfront that our prison authorities will not tolerate any form of abuse or assaults on inmates in our prisons, committed either by other inmates or by its officers. When such an incident is detected or brought to the attention of any prison officer, immediate action is taken to protect the victim and provide him with appropriate medical care. The incident is then thoroughly investigated and the perpetrators brought to task. 

 

     The prison environment is a unique and challenging one.  About 12,600 inmates, some with violent criminal backgrounds, live in close proximity to one another.  They are there not by choice, but because they have to serve out their sentences imposed by the courts.  Realistically, when such inmates live in close confinements with each other, we must expect that there will be friction and conflict, resulting in some occurrence of bullying and threats and the occasional assault, particularly amongst younger inmates.  The role of the prison authorities is to put in place processes to minimise such occurrence of violence, facilitate reporting by a victimised inmate of any abuse and take firm disciplinary action against those who breach prison regulations.  In serious cases, prison authorities will not hesitate to have the perpetrator charged in court.

 

     Dr Lam Pin Min, Mr Christopher de Souza and Ms Sylvia Lim asked about measures taken to prevent abuse and assaults in prisons. Ms Lim has also asked about the criteria to determine cell-sharing arrangements.  Sir, as I shared at the Committee of Supply debate earlier this year, Prisons has well-established procedures and safeguards for the safe and secure custody of inmates.  These include body searches, regular patrols, muster checks and interviews by prison officers who act as personal supervisors.  The cells also have distress intercoms which inmates can activate when in need of assistance.  These measures have also enabled prison officers to detect assaults in our prisons.

 

     In addition, Prisons assesses the inmate’s security risk when he is incarcerated.  It takes into account various factors when determining cell-sharing arrangements of inmates, so as to minimise the incidence of abuse or assaults.  They include the inmate’s age, his antecedents, if any, the nature of the offence for which he is in prison and the risk of him committing violence and harming himself.

 

     Inmates with a high security risk are housed alone in a cell and closely supervised for security reasons. For medium and low risk inmates, they will be housed with other inmates in cells.  In the current case of interest, the inmate and the three assailants were all young offenders, with similar types of antecedents and were assessed to be of medium security risk.  They were housed together in a standard cell installed with a distress intercom system.

 

     Let me emphasise, however, that despite all these measures, no system is foolproof.  Whilst Prisons will do its best to prevent and detect such incidents, inmates must also take responsibility for their personal safety, for example, by complying with prison rules and regulations themselves.  They should not try to conceal any abuse or incidence of violence and try to resolve disputes on their own.  Inmates who are threatened by fellow inmates or are assaulted should report the matter immediately.

 

     Prisons provides ample avenues of reporting.  Besides any prison officer on duty and their personal supervisor, they can also raise any request or complaint with the volunteers, with the Superintendent of the prison or indeed with the Visiting Justices during their regular visits.

 

     An inmate who informs of imminent harm or bullying is immediately sent for medical examination and treatment.  He is also segregated for his personal safety and may be transferred to a another institution, if necessary.

 

     The facts of the recent High Court case where an inmate suffered serious injuries as a result of being assaulted by his cellmates in Changi Prison Complex have been amply aired in court.  I will not go into the details but we should see this incident in perspective.

 

     This incident is an isolated one in terms of the seriousness of the injuries sustained and the intensity and duration of the assaults.  What is of critical importance is that the victim had numerous opportunities over the period the assaults occurred, to report them to the many different prison officers he came into contact with each day, such as when he and his cellmates were unlocked for yard time and during the physical muster checks by staff which are conducted three times a day.

 

     He could also have activated the distress intercom in his cell to seek help any time.  The incident would not have remained undetected over eight days, nor would it have escalated to the extent that it did if only the inmate had sought help earlier.  Unfortunately, for reasons best known to him, he chose to remain silent.

 

     After more than a week, the inmate finally decided to report sick to seek medical attention.  He activated the distress intercom in his cell.  Even then, he was not forthcoming in revealing to the prison officer and the staff nurse initially on what had happened and had told staff that he felt unwell because of a fall.  It was only after persistent questioning that he informed the authorities that he had been assaulted by his cellmates.  So, whilst we sympathise with him for the pain and suffering he went through, he did not help the situation at all by not reporting the assault to a prison officer earlier.

 

     The Director of Prisons has carefully reviewed the circumstances of the case and has not found any of the prisons officers involved to have been professionally remiss.  Indeed, they took swift action on discovering the assault and rendered prompt medical attention to the victim.  Prisons also reported the matter to the Police to initiate criminal investigations against the assailants so that they would face the full brunt of the law in court.

 

     More generally, Dr Lam asked about the incidence of prison abuse over the last five years.  Prisons measures the level of physical violence in prison by tracking the number of major assaults on inmates and prison staff annually, which includes both fights between inmates where serious injuries are inflicted and also abuse cases where there are elements of bullying or threats used against the inmate leading to serious injury.

 

     The rates of major assaults per 10,000 inmates from FY 2004 to FY 2008 are 13.5, 16.2, 15, 22.3 and 35.2 respectively.  The increase in FY 2008 is largely due to a review of Prisons' institutional offence guidelines, leading to more cases being classified as major assaults.  There is generally no decline in the level of institutional discipline.  Most of the assaults in prisons are one-off assaults arising from arguments that take place at the spur of the moment.  Only a small number of the cases have elements of bullying, threats and intimidation used against the victim.  Indeed, our major assault rates are also low by international standards and are achieved despite a lean staff to inmate ratio.  For example, the reported figures are 46 in New Zealand and 165 in England.

 

     Dr Lam also asked for data on prison officers abusing inmates.  Whilst we expect the highest level of professional conduct from our prison officers, sporadically, some fall prey to provocation and lapses of good judgment.  In the past five years, there were 14 cases where inappropriate force was used on an inmate, or about three cases per year on average.  None of the cases resulted in serious injuries to the inmates.  All these officers were all duly punished according to civil service disciplinary rules.

 

     Our prison authorities continually explore ways to improve the administration of our prisons.  Even though there are already a slew of safeguards in place to address the issues of abuse and assaults, nevertheless, in light of the latest incident, a review was conducted and additional resources were deployed to enhance monitoring of inmates.  However, I must reiterate the point that it is not possible to eliminate all forms of negative behaviour between inmates within a prison environment.  What is important is that inmates must also take responsibility for their own well-being.  If they do so, like I have given the assurance just now, there are effective processes and structures in place for their concerns to be addressed.

 

     Mr de Souza asked if the prison authorities are willing to consider the advice of relevant external parties on prisons discipline.  Prison authorities are indeed open to the valuable feedback and suggestions from the Board of Visiting Justices, the Board of Visitors and its large core of committed volunteers as to how our prisons’ security and rehabilitation processes can be further improved.  Their suggestions are studied closely.

 

     In fact, to render prison’s institutional discipline processes more transparent and rigorous, Prisons set up an Institutional Discipline Review Committee about a year ago.  This Committee, comprising reputable members of the public, including quite a few with existing or previous legal and judicial backgrounds, advises the Director of Prisons as to whether the institutional caning awarded against a prisoner for an aggravated institutional offence is, in their view, excessive.

 

     Sir, in summary, let me assure Members that, notwithstanding this case, our prison remains one of the safest in the world.  Moreover, our prison authorities will not tolerate any form of abuse or assault by inmates or staff, sparing no effort to ensure that any perpetrator is immediately brought to task.  Inmates, on their part, must exercise responsibility for their own safety by reporting such incidents early to the prison officers as there are ample opportunities for them to do so.

     Dr Lam Pin Min:  Sir, I would like to thank the Senior Minister of State for the very comprehensive answer and the reassurances.  But I must admit that when I read the recent report, I was shocked to find that the victim was actually subjected to physical and sexual abuses over a period of eight days under the watchful eyes of the prison service in Changi.  This only reminded me of the scenes in the Hong Kong blockbuster movie Prison on Fire –

     Mr Speaker: Ask your question, Dr Lam.

     Dr Lam Pin Min:  Sir, my question is that it is unimaginable that over eight days, the prison officers could not detect anything unusual about the abuse that this victim was subjected to.  Surely there must be a way where prison officers can be trained to detect such abuses.  I think we should not put most of the responsibility on the prison inmates themselves.

 

     Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee:   Sir, as I have said, there are operational procedures which at least try to ensure that the inmates are safe, but no system is foolproof.  For example, I mentioned that there are muster checks three times daily.  Body searches are also carried out on inmates.  Cells also have the distress intercom that will enable any inmate who feels threatened or unsafe and who is beaten up to actually make a report.  That is the key point.


The key point is that we cannot think of every conceivable eventuality that may happen in prison.  What Prisons must do is to provide a system which is generally safe and that is a point I want to reiterate.  Our assault rates are low compared to many in the world and, indeed, many inmates come out from the prison gates rehabilitated.
 
     But there are also inmates, because of their own backgrounds, because of their own attitudes, may themselves engage in risky behaviour.  If we follow the case in the papers closely, this inmate was like that, because he himself had been disciplined in prison before for assaulting other people.  So, when it happened, if he had reported it early through any officer on the first day, or on the second day, this would not have happened.  That is the point that is best reminding.  Otherwise, we think that for eight or nine days they were unreported, why did it happen?
 
     The Director of Prisons, as I have said, has carried out a very careful review of the relevant officers who had come in contact with the inmate and he is satisfied that no officer has been professionally remiss.  They did what they were supposed to do.  But for reasons which, in fact, also came out in the court trial, one reason the inmate himself offered was that perhaps because he had a dark complexion, the injuries were not detected.  The injuries remained undetected until finally, he disclosed them to the officers.

 

    Ms Sylvia Lim (Non-Constituency Member):   Supplementary questions.  Sir, earlier the Senior Minister of State recited these figures of assault in our prisons and compared them internationally to other countries and said that they were low.  But, Sir, during the trial, it was quite obvious from the testimony of the inmates in the cell as well as those in the neighbouring cells that, generally, they do not resort to reporting as a first recourse when they hear something suspicious or something has happened to them.  Some of them said in the court that they did not want any trouble even though they heard something in the neighbouring cell, they did not want to report it for avoidance of trouble.  So, does the Minister not agree with me that actually those figures that we have are only the figures that we know of and there is probably a significant under-reporting of such incidents in our prison?

The success rate of applicants is therefore determined by the status of whether they are first-timer or otherwise, and not by their age.  Many of the elderly have benefited from our public housing schemes earlier in their lives and, if so, they are considered second timers, and will be accorded lower priority. Elderly who are first-time applicants will enjoy the same chances as their younger counterparts.
 
     Sir, in recognition of the unique housing needs of the elderly, HDB has introduced the Studio Apartment for those 55 years or older.  Studio Apartments are sold with a shorter lease of 30 years and come with elder-friendly features such as lever taps and hand bars.  They have been very popular with close to 100% take-up rate.  HDB will continue to build more of them. One thousand more units are planned for launch over the next two years.
 
      To meet the needs of an ageing population, we have also put in place an array of monetisation options to enable elderly home owners to unlock their flat equity to support their retirement.  Downgrading to a Studio Apartment or a smaller resale flat is one way to unlock flat equity.  The elderly can also choose to sell or sublet their flat and stay with their children.  HDB has progressively relaxed its whole flat subletting rules to allow more lessees to do so.

CHILDREN NOT SUPPORTING ELDERLY PARENTS

     10.  Ms Denise Phua Lay Peng asked the Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports whether the Ministry will consider a solution package, with timeframes and ownerships, to address the problem of elderly parents whose able children are unwilling to support them, especially financially.

     The Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports (Dr Vivian Balakrishnan):   Mr Speaker, Sir, a fundamental principle of our society is the concept of filial piety.  At a practical level, what that means is that we have to support our ageing parents. 

 

     Unfortunately, I think Members in this House would all have come across cases, not common but not rare either, circumstances in which you will see that some aged parents are not getting the support that they deserve from their children.  Sometimes, it is because there is a problem with the relationship.  Other times, this dispute is really between siblings on how to adequately share the responsibility of looking after their parents.  But whatever the case may be they often result in a situation in which the elderly parents are left to their own devices or they are forced to seek assistance from charitable organisations or from the State. This is unacceptable and unfair.  It is unfair to the parents.  It is unfair to the charitable organisations and it is unfair to the taxpayers.  Over the last 12 months, there has been a total of 172 applications filed at the Tribunal for Maintenance of Parents.  The usual annual rate is about 100.  So over the last 12 months, there has been a significant increase in the number of applications filed.

 

     Consequently, there are three areas my Ministry is focusing on in response to this escalating situation. 

 

     First, we will tighten the workflow and referral processes and the information flow between agencies in dealing with this.  Let me give Members an example. Of the elderly who approach the CDCs for financial assistance, we have found that nearly one third do not even have the contact details of their children. This makes it more difficult obviously for the CDCs to process the applications and also to check on whether the children are available and able to support their parents.  We are exploring how the relevant information from different Ministries, different agencies can be shared without compromising privacy and confidentiality.  But, nevertheless, we see that the information can flow safely and appropriately so that we can deal with the cases comprehensively.

 

     Secondly, we are looking at strengthening the office of the Commissioner for Maintenance of Parents.  Under the Act, the Commissioner already has legal powers to act on behalf of the elderly parent before the Tribunal.  In the future, I have requested that the Commissioner play a more active and effective role in case monitoring and advocacy, in facilitating mediation and conciliation, and also for ensuring proactively that the elderly receive prompt assistance.  My Ministry will therefore increase the resources available to the Commissioner's office so that all these things can be done.

 

     The third area is to ensure that elderly parents who are caught in this situation receive timely and comprehensive assistance.  The ComCare schemes already provide for urgent interim assistance to any needy parents who need help.  The elderly parents who are caught in such a situation can, of course, see the local advisors and can access the schemes delivered through ComCare.  But in addition to that, I think there is also a need to provide more information to the elderly parents so that they are aware of their options.  Many of them will not want to initiate legal action in the first instance.  But, nevertheless, we are going to refer them to the Tribunal, refer them to the Commissioner's office so that they know that these options are available.  They will be able to consider whether or when to initiate legal actions.  Even if they do not pursue these legal actions, the Commissioner's office can, as I said earlier, assist the elderly parents with managing the complex, social and family problems which they often are caught in.  So the key point is to provide timely, effective and comprehensive assistance to the elderly parents at the point of need.

 

     I want to end by saying that legislation and legal actions have to be the last resort.  We cannot legislate love nor can you use legislation in this House to guarantee emotional support.  We know that the vast majority of families in Singapore are still strong and instinctively abide by the concept of filial piety.  Our ageing Singaporeans deserve to be surrounded by a strong network of close family ties.  But we will know that there is a small minority that will need help and what we will focus on is ensuring that for this small minority, help and recourse will be available and in a timely and effective way.  Our job is to make the entire process as efficient and effective as possible basically so that those who are even contemplating abdicating their responsibility will know that the system will catch up with them and this is not a path of least resistance.   I am also studying the possibility of amending the Act and I look forward to receiving suggestions from Members of this House as well as members of the public on how we can further strengthen the  Maintenance of Parents Act.

NATION BUILDING TENETS

(Motion)

 

     Order read for resumption of debate on Question [18th August, 2009],

 

     "That this House reaffirms its commitment to the nation building tenets as enshrined in the National Pledge when debating national policies, especially economic policies.". – [Mr Viswa Sadasivan].

 

     Question again proposed.

 

 

     Mr Zainudin Nordin (Bishan-Toa Payoh): Mr Speaker, Sir, allow me to recite the Pledge:

 

     "We, the citizens of Singapore, pledge ourselves as one united people, regardless of race, language or religion, to build a democratic society based on justice and equality so as to achieve happiness, prosperity and progress for our nation."

 

     Sir, upon closer scrutiny of the Pledge, I realised that the Pledge only comprises three sentences.  Because in those three, albeit long, sentences is captured the essence of how we should live our lives as Singaporeans, and what we want for Singapore.  It is somewhat like a Vision Statement.

 

     To me, Sir, the most poignant statement is the line, "regardless of race, language or religion, to build a democratic society based on justice and equality".  Each time I read this line, I feel a sense of purpose and pride as a Singaporean.  This is the heart of the Pledge.  It is the one organ that is responsible for supplying the body with oxygenated blood.  Each time the heart beats, it applies just the right pressure on the veins and arteries for the blood supply throughout our body.  Hence, this statement in the Pledge is the key element that underpins our belief in the plurality of our nation.

 

     This year, we celebrate 50 years of self-government.  It is worthwhile for us in this House to reflect honestly on what we have attained.  As this year's national song title asked us, "What do you see?", and I also would like to ask this House, "What kind of Singapore have we built?"

 

     Yesterday, as I sat in this Chamber and listened to Mr Viswa Sadasivan, this was the picture that was painted: 

 

     –  we are more an "Inc" than a "nation", more concerned  about the bottomlines and KPIs;

 

     –  we lack freedom of expression, as Singaporeans live in a "climate of fear";

 

     –  we are a society confused by the mixed signals;

 

     –  this is a country that takes its "citizens for granted";

 

     –  the Government lacks accountability to its people, and he said, "accountability requires the Government to go beyond lip-service ...".

 

     He also mentioned that we do not care enough for our old and needy; and we lack justice and fairness, and to quote him, "When justice, especially in the way it is meted out, deviates significantly from the common man's sense of fairness, questions of legitimacy arise."

 

     To be honest, Sir, I was worried.  I ask myself – is this really what Singapore is today?  Is that what we have become after 50 years of nation building?

 

     Mr Speaker, Sir, I think and I feel that this is not what Singapore is today.  We have built and done much more for our country.  Let us not be too harsh on ourselves.

 

     Allow me, Sir, to cite some of the good work our forefathers, leaders and citizens have done that resulted in this country that we are enjoying today.

 

     Racial and religious harmony was not a natural instinct when we attained self-government 50 years ago.  The multi-racial and multi-religious profile of our country posed a big challenge for the government of the day as there were potential community fault lines that could scuttle the good work that needed to be done.  The harmony that we have today was made possible through the will and determination of our founding fathers.  Many would not even know that 34 people were killed and 563 injured in two outbreaks of racial riots in 1964.  But Singaporeans of that era, shocked by the horror of those riots, have resolved from then on never to take racial harmony for granted.

 

     Singapore, in the 50s and early 60s, was not too much different from the preceding century, where identity was concerned. Singapore had developed and thrived since our founding as a motley mix of immigrants, united by the necessary business of making a living.  A sense of community and common destiny was gathering momentum, however, forged by the experience of the war years.

 

     At the heart of the challenge to turn Singapore into a functioning state was the handling of our racial relations.  It is no understatement to say that our efforts at instilling racial harmony are primarily responsible for the tremendous economic success and political stability we enjoyed in the last five decades.

 

     Since the early days of our nationhood, we have worked hard at maintaining peace and stability for our country.  But maintaining racial harmony is a long journey, and we would be foolish to assume that we have arrived.  We only have to look at the ill-fated first steps of our journey as a nation to realise how fragile race relations can be.

 

 

     The lessons of the racial riots in the 1960s remain an indelible part of our history.  Everyone whose lives were touched by the riots understood how we all lost when racial differences spilled over into actual conflict.  Lives were lost, work slowed down, there were food shortages, hawkers could not conduct their business, and children could not go to school.  It was a setback for all of us, and generations after have remained convinced that we cannot afford to ever bring ourselves down that road again.  We cannot afford  a repeat of the panic and irrational fear that led to segregation of the races after the two riots of 1964.  Houses and buildings can be rebuilt in a flash, but trust and harmony take generations to restore.

 

 

     Peace and harmony did not happen today by chance.  Our leaders made that one decision never to allow these events to happen again.  Yes, we cannot erase race and religion from society.  Indeed, race and religion run so deep in our lives that it is unthinkable to try and remove them.  It is like the East and the West, and never the twain shall meet.  But that does not mean we cannot get them to communicate and to maintain harmony.  So, our leaders created a new set of values that could be commonly accepted by the different communities – the principles of meritocracy, justice and equality.

 

     What has been the outcome?  Where there were squatters and swamps, we turned them into housing estates and playgrounds.  Where there were sorrows and sufferings, we brought happiness, comfort and relief.  We gave jobs to the people, we trained the untrained so that they could get reemployed.  We helped the poor not through the outright handouts, but through a deliberate policy to give them the tools to enable them to break out of the snares of poverty.  Education is compulsory and dote on each child through their school years to ensure that by the time they leave, they are equipped, if not academically, then technically.  Not one is disadvantaged because of his or her race or religion.  You name the professions, be it medical, legal, accounting, engineering, banking, and they are all there – Chinese, Indians, Tamils, Malays, Eurasians and more.

     The policies have worked.  The people across all races know this.  These policies benefit everyone, everywhere, everyday.  Therefore, in this motion before the House, while it offers us the opportunity to discuss the issue of nation building, I think we can do better.

     Do not misunderstand me.  I am not saying that the western model of democracy is wrong – I am just saying that their model, which even differs from western country to western country, is but one possible model of democracy.  Most political theorists would agree that democracy is a system of governance "of the people, by the people, and for the people".  Beyond this three-part description, there is enormous dispute over what democracy is. 

 

 

     For example, should democracy be simply a system of majority-rule, or should a protection of the minority, the minority who would lose in a democratic vote, be also protected? Is a representative democracy where citizens elect representatives to govern for a period of time sufficiently democratic, or is a truly democratic system direct democracy, where citizens vote directly on the enactment of laws and policies as much as possible?  These are all questions that, when answered, lead to different models of democracy.

For example, if we believe that there should be a protection of minority rights in a truly democratic society, and that simple majority-rule is not sufficiently democratic, then Singaporeans must ask themselves whether sometimes, even if the majority feels a certain way, the minority still deserves to be protected. For example, I think it was this sort of thinking that led to the debate on the repeal of section 377A.

 

     Yet, not all minorities can be protected – this is simply neither possible nor practical. If we do, every group with special tastes, with unique preferences, will be able to claim protection, and the smallest minority is a minority of one.  In practice, even if we think that democracy requires us to protect minorities, there needs to be a balance when formulating national policies that takes them into consideration. It is my opinion that the best form of protection for minorities is the equal regard that all individuals get in the eyes of the law.

 

     Our founding fathers have, like in many countries, chosen a system of representative democracy, specifically parliamentary democracy, as Singapore’s system of government. In a system of representative democracy, regular elections are held to decide who will form the government, rather than to decide the issues of the day.


     Once elected, a government has the authority to formulate policy and enact legislation, until it loses its mandate in the elected chamber, or when fresh elections are called. Singapore has this system, and with variations, so do countries such as the US, Britain and many democratic countries.  On the other hand, Switzerland has a system of government that incorporates more elements of direct democracy, where ordinary citizens can propose legislation, and referenda are regularly called for the citizens to vote on.  If one day, Singaporeans were to think that this is the sort of democracy they want, and this is the type of democratic society they want to build, they must do so with their eyes open to the practical implications. For example, direct democracy is very time consuming and citizens have to educate themselves about the proposed legislation before voting in the referenda, turning up on voting day to vote, and do this several  times a year!  For Singaporeans who even now complain that they do not even have time to make babies, they should especially make sure that they consider carefully!


     I have not yet heard strident calls for more direct democracy, but another more important debate about the form that democracy should take will be more familiar and significant to Singaporeans – voting procedure. In Singapore, some political parties have called for a system of proportional representation to replace the current "first-past-the-post" system. In the current system, it is possible for a party with 51% of the popular vote to win 100% of the parliamentary seats. To some, this is unfair – the Workers' Party, for example, in its manifesto, calls for "An alternative system of proportional representation ... that could reflect party votes at the national level".


     There are strengths and weaknesses to both systems, and both are used by democratic countries elsewhere. In deciding what sort of democratic society they want to build, Singaporeans should be aware of the practical implications of both. In a first-past-the-post system, stable governments with clear majorities are more likely. This, if I am not wrong, has been the view of the People’s Action Party. A proportional representation system, because it allows smaller parties with small proportions of the popular vote to gain seats, is more likely to result in a proliferation of parties in Parliament, and thus a need for coalition governments. Experience in other countries has shown us that coalition governments tend to be more unstable and weak, leading to more frequent elections.

Yet, the supporters of a proportional representation system are not wrong: it is a fairer, more proportionate system that more accurately reflects voter preferences. There is something intuitively unfair that a party with 51% of the popular vote could technically end up with all the seats in Parliament. In deciding what sort of voting system will help Singapore build a more democratic society, Singaporeans should thus be very aware of the costs and benefits of both systems in practice, and choose very carefully. When theory becomes practice, and when idealism is tempered by pragmatism, an idea that may sound very attractive conceptually may not be so easy to implement in reality.

Justice, equality and fairness are thus ideas that are inextricably linked.


     However, when Singaporeans put their hands to their hearts and pledge to build a society based on equality, what do they exactly mean? What is equality?  There are many ways to discuss this but I would like to focus on two meanings of equality that I think are most important to Singaporeans and, depending on which meaning they believe in more, would shape their thoughts about what national policies, especially economic policies, should be formulated to build a society based on equality.  The first is equality of opportunity and the second equality of outcome.

 


     I think equality of opportunity can best be encapsulated by the phrase, "a level playing field".  It means that whoever we are, wherever we come from, regardless of what socio-economic group we are born into, or gender, or race, we have an equal chance to succeed in life. It is this type of equality that I think underpins a meritocratic society.  A society that offers an equality of opportunity will have institutions that are blind to the differences I talked about – class, gender, race – and every man, every woman, would have, in theory, an equal chance to get into the best schools, obtain the best jobs, or even run for the highest political offices in the land. A society based on the equality of opportunity strives to ensure that each citizen is not disadvantaged by any discrimination.


     Fundamental to the idea of equality of opportunity is the principle of dessert. The thought goes like this: if the playing field is equal and nobody is unfairly disadvantaged, and if everyone has an equal opportunity to succeed, then the outcome must also be fair and just. Whether you win or lose, you have an equal chance to succeed. If you are one of the winners, your prize is well-deserved. If you are one of the losers, you have nobody to blame, as you had an equal chance to succeed, but you did not.  But is this really just?


     There is a fundamental weakness to the idea of equality of opportunity and this is it: no matter how level the playing field is, no matter how fair the rules of the game are, some of us are always more likely to lose. This is because even if opportunities are equal, human beings are not born with equal talents. When I was young, I was pretty sure I had an equal chance to become a star basketball player or even a supermodel, in so far that there are no laws in Singapore that stop me from doing so. That I am neither now is not a reflection of unequal opportunity, but the fact that I am challenged in terms of height and in looks, something that I was born with through no fault of mine.

 

     The role that luck plays in our lives is also very important, when judging whether mere equality of opportunity is enough to create a just society. As the cliché goes, accidents happen, and like most clichés, there is truth in it. Sometimes people do badly in life not because they are lazy, or made the wrong decisions, or are unwilling to try, but because they are plain unlucky. This is not shifting blame or avoiding responsibility, but a very real fact of life. For instance, illness could incapacitate an otherwise talented man in the prime of his life.


     The fact of the matter is this: equal opportunity may lead to unequal outcomes, and these unequal outcomes sometimes outrage our sense of justice. This leads me to the other very important meaning of equality: equality of outcome.


     As my colleague Mr Viswa has pointed out, Singapore has a relatively high income inequality, closer to the standards of under-developed countries in the world; its income inequality, as represented by the Gini coefficient, is higher than many of our neighbouring countries. Income inequality is an inequality of outcome. The important question is this: Even if we accept that Singapore is meritocratic, and even if the Government has successfully ensured a more or less even playing field and equality of opportunity to all citizens, it remains a fact that Singapore has one of the highest income inequalities in the region.


     Can we as a people accept that this inequality is just, that this inequality is fair? Is equality of opportunity all we need to care about when we pledge to build a society based on equality?


     As I argued before, equality of opportunity and a meritocratic system can still produce very unequal results because people are born with different abilities, or are just plain unlucky even if they are hardworking, committed or even talented.


     The important issue is thus this: if we believe that unequal outcomes that arise from equal opportunities are still unjust, then we have to do something about it and the only thing we can do is to tweak the outcome. That is where the problem starts because when translated into practical economic policies, it reveals a tension between the two types of inequalities.

 

     Let us go back to a practical issue – the very important issue of income inequality.  If we believe that it is unjust for some people to be very rich whilst others hover on the edges of poverty, regardless of whether they had an equal opportunity to succeed, then one of the most powerful ways to address this inequality is to redistribute income. But by redistributing income, by taking away some from the rich and giving it to the poor, through taxation for example, we are actually telling the winners this: that though your rewards may have been justly won, through you taking your opportunity, through your hard work, your industry, we are nevertheless taking some of these rewards away from you, and giving them to those who have lost out, so we have a more equal outcome. To some of these winners, this may seem not only unequal, but outright unfair and unjust – they succeeded fairly and squarely, and yet do not get to enjoy the full fruits of their labour. Perhaps this is the reason why advocates of low income tax are convinced that higher taxes will discourage industry and impede meritocracy. On the practical level, the policy level, a belief in equality of opportunity is thus not wholly compatible with a desire to see more equal outcomes.


     In his speech, my colleague Mr Viswa talked about spending more money on public assistance to the poor and the needy. This is necessarily also redistributive in nature, and focuses on creating a more equal outcome, or at least reducing inequalities. Yet, this is what must be done if Singaporeans are convinced that the equality that they believe in, the equality that they pledge to, is not merely an equal opportunity to succeed, but also a more equal society on the whole. If, on the other hand, Singaporeans believe that as long as our society is meritocratic and we all have an equal opportunity to succeed, that this sort of equality is enough to build a just society, then the national and economic policies they support will be vastly different – perhaps a regime very much like the one we have now, lower income taxes, less redistributive economic policies and an ethos that focuses more on people having an equal start to life, rather than an equal end to it.

     Democracy and justice – I am not saying that the Government is stuffing ballot boxes or doing things that are non-Constitutional.  I was highlighting a lingering perception that I sensed on the ground that politically, it is not a level playing field and if we do not address this, there will be growing cynicism especially amongst our youth who will choose to express their displeasure through angry postings in the Net which is not useful.

 

     Thirdly, on economic progress and happiness. I did not say economic prosperity is not important and that it should be put on the back burner.  It would be naive to promote an argument of that nature.  What I was highlighting was that national economic progress must result in happiness for the individual and this may not always be the case.

 

     My intention in moving this motion was not to take shots at the Government or its policies. It must be evident in my speech that I have a healthy regard for the Government and appreciation for what we have achieved, and that we should not take that for granted.  My motivation is simple.  As a citizen of this country, I am deeply concerned about the level of rootedness and the latent threats to harmony that if these two issues are not adequately addressed, we may not succeed as a nation, a people.  For this, we need an emotional anchor or a collective reflex for which I am confident our National Pledge would serve as a reference point.

 

     I am glad that we have had a chance to have this discussion.  I do believe it is useful and I do believe it would provoke further discussion on the Pledge and the importance of some of the tenets of the Pledge on the ground.  I think it is important for us to move away from hardline positions and look a lot more at shared interests, and there are plenty of shared interests even as we discussed and debated the various points.

 

     We can disagree on the substantive issues I raised but I would find it very hard if Members cannot accept that we as Members of this House do see and should see the importance of re-affirming our commitment to the key tenets of the National Pledge.

 

     I am confident that the House will support the amended version of the motion and once again my sincere thanks to Members for actively participating in the debate on this motion, and provoking thought and discussion on the National Pledge in society.

MRT STATIONS
(No eating and drinking rule)

     14.   Mdm Cynthia Phua asked the Minister for Transport in view of the tightening of the "No eating/drinking" rule in the MRT stations, (a) how many people were fined for eating and drinking in the MRT stations since May this year; (b) what is the guideline for the definition of "eating"; and (c) whether the Ministry will consider allowing passengers to put sweets in their mouth as some elderly people have to do this to overcome motion sickness.

     

     15.   Dr Lim Wee Kiak asked the Minister for Transport in view of the recent case where a commuter was caught eating a sweet in an MRT train (a) what were the circumstances that led to the issuance of a fine; (b) why was the commuter’s explanation not accepted and the commuter not let off with a warning; (c) how serious is the problem of eating/drinking in MRT trains; and (d) whether there is a public education campaign to raise awareness about this regulation. 

     Mr Raymond Lim Siang Keat:

     Under the Rapid Transit Systems (RTS) Regulations, passengers who consume or attempt to consume any food, drinks, chewing or bubble gum in the MRT stations and trains are liable to a fine of up to $500. Offences may be compounded by the LTA to lesser amounts such as $30.  This Regulation has been in place since the start of MRT services in 1987, to ensure cleanliness and hygiene in the stations and trains.

 

      Most passengers comply with the Regulation of not eating and drinking in stations and trains.  However, there is a small but growing group of passengers who do not. The number of Notices of Offences issued in 2006 was 301. This had increased to 581 in 2007 and 646 in 2008. In the first six months of 2009, there were 281 offences.  To put these numbers in perspective, there are nearly 1.5 million trips a day made on our train system.  The percentage of offenders is low and most Singaporeans are considerate passengers who do not inconvenience their fellow commuters.

 

     However, the operators decided to step up enforcement recently after a surge in public complaints against eating and drinking in trains.  Let me give just one example. On 9th July 2009, Mr Loke Parc Sen wrote to the Straits Times Interactive, expressing concern that when a commuter was caught eating on the train, he: "dared the SMRT officer by saying: 'Fine me; I don't care.' Seeing that these are the kind of characters they are dealing with, SMRT should show no mercy. Letting them off with a warning or a meagre fine of $30 is a slap on the wrist. I suggest they be made to feel the full consequence of their choice – a $500 fine."

 

     Mdm Phua and Dr Lim asked whether exceptions can be considered, for instance, allowing the elderly to eat sweets to overcome motion sickness, to manage diabetes or for other reasons.  My Ministry, and I am sure the operators as well, recognise that there could indeed be extenuating circumstances. However, these are exceptional situations rather than the norm.  Practically, it would be impossible to comprehensively define such circumstances upfront – they are, by definition, exceptional and should be dealt with on a case-by-case basis.

 

     As I mentioned earlier, our principal aim is to ensure cleanliness and hygiene on the trains and stations for the benefit of all passengers. Thus, passengers should finish eating or drinking before entering the MRT station. If they really need to eat or drink for medical or other special reasons, they should approach the MRT station staff. The MRT station staff are trained to exercise flexibility and judgment.  Sometimes, this may mean granting an exception; other times it may mean saying, no.  If indeed there are genuine cases of service lapses, passengers can report them to the operators.

 

    Dr Lim asked if there is a public education campaign to raise awareness of this Regulation against eating or drinking in stations and trains. Over the years, the rail operators have indeed undertaken several public education programmes to encourage gracious behaviour, including not eating or drinking in stations and trains. For example, SMRT and SBST engage the public through their on-going Learning Journey programmes with primary and secondary schools, the annual SMRT Courtesy and Safety Programme and SBST’s quarterly Community Engagement Programme. As recently as May this year, the Public Transport Council launched a public education programme, in partnership with the operators, to promote gracious behaviour on public transport. There are also regular audio broadcasts in MRT stations reminding passengers not to eat or drink.  Through such efforts, we hope to raise awareness of the need to be considerate to other passengers. This will help provide a more pleasant travelling experience for all.

PUBLIC FUNDS ACCOUNTABILITY

     16.   Mdm Ho Geok Choo asked the Minister for Finance in light of the latest Auditor-General’s Report on lapses in the Civil Service, how can prudence and accountability in the use of public money be further nurtured.

     Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam:

     The Auditor-General’s Report indicates the need to continually enhance prudence and accountability in the use of public monies. The Ministry of Finance (MOF) is addressing this through a Whole-of-Government framework for use of public monies.  The framework comprises five main thrusts:

 

     First, instituting controls.  MOF puts in place expenditure policies, rules, procedures, limits and norms to ensure budgetary prudence and accountability. These policies and rules are issued to all Government agencies for compliance. 

 

     Second, encouraging best practices.  MOF promotes Best Practices at the Whole-of-Government level to drive better usage of resources. Best Sourcing and Public-Private Partnerships are examples of such initiatives.  Advisories such as on advertising and public relations expenditures are also issued to provide guidance for agencies.

 

     Third, promoting a mindset of thrift.  Efforts are made to raise awareness of public servants on the need to be prudent in expenditure and ensure value for money through the Economy Drive, and the Cut Waste Panel, which is chaired by public sector leaders. 

 

     Fourth, developing capabilities.  MOF has established a competency and training framework to systematically develop officers across Government agencies with the necessary skills to undertake budgeting and procurement work proficiently.

 

     Fifth, monitoring performance. MOF works closely with the Ministries to identify and review their strategic outcomes, outcome and performance indicators annually to ensure accountability.

 

     In line with these five strategic thrusts, MOF has launched a number of important initiatives in recent years to further promote prudence and accountability:

 

     A Value-for-Money (VFM) Office, established in 2007, enables MOF to systematically examine whether Government expenditures are achieving their intended outcomes and doing so in a cost-efficient way.  What VFM amounts to is a selective, ex-post review of Ministries’ budgeting decisions – either for an individual Ministry or at a Whole-Of-Government level. VFM audits hence provide an important complement to the system of block budgeting, which gives Ministries autonomy over the internal allocation of their block budgets.

 

     We are also making progress in ensuring effective land and building usage and management. Among other measures, MOF has revised the office space norms for public agencies last year to ensure more efficient use of space.

 

     MOF will continually review our framework and will be following up with agencies identified in the Auditor-General's Office (AGO) report to further enhance prudence and accountability.  Even with a rigorous framework of rules and guidelines, there will unfortunately be instances of lapses. What is important is to have such lapses picked up in time and thereafter distilled as lessons. By doing so, we minimise the chances of bigger or more systemic problems occurring. 

 

    To specifically address the lapses in Procurement and Contract Management, MOF is implementing a new Procurement Competency and Training Framework that is aimed at raising the capability of public officers in procurement and contract management.  A forum would also be conducted in October 2009 to cover lessons learnt from AGO’s observations.

HOME-BASED CARE

     18.   Dr Lam Pin Min asked the Minister for Health in view of the rapidly ageing population and the increasing demand for home-based care, what are the Ministry's middle to long-term strategies in developing this sector of healthcare in Singapore. 

     Mr Khaw Boon Wan:

     As a policy, we support the idea that all seniors should age at home, and not have to rely on long-term institutional care.  The vast majority of the elderly are generally healthy and are able to age at home.  A small minority will however require long-term medical or nursing care.  Where it is not practical to provide such professional care at home, admission to a nursing home becomes inevitable.  But we should try to avoid such an outcome as far as practicable.  Where it is cost-effective to bring medical or nursing care to the patients at home, we should try to facilitate it.  This is also the preferred option by the seniors as they can then remain in a familiar environment, and be in the company of their family members.

 

     Currently, home healthcare is not a big part of our healthcare sector.  But as our population ages further, we can expect the demand for it to grow.  Thus, an important part of our strategy for home care is to ensure there is sufficient capacity in the sector to meet the growing demand. This means an adequate supply of healthcare workers, including doctors, nurses, therapists and other allied health professionals.  We are ramping up their numbers through increased training and foreign recruitment. We will also need to expand the number of daycare centres, in tandem with rising demand.  

 

     Second, we will enhance the capabilities of our home care services. We will need to raise their professional skills and standards so that they are confident to care for the seniors in the community. My Ministry has now extended its support to the training and professional development of healthcare workers from the home care sector through the Health Manpower Development Programme. As the sector grows, we will increase funding for training in home care. 

 

     Third, we want to make home care more affordable through gradually extending the 3Ms framework to long-term care and home care. As a first step, we have decided to extend Medisave to cover home palliative care. As we gain more experience with this pilot, we will consider how the scheme can be further extended to other home care services. 

 

     Fourth, we will work with the home care providers to improve the coordination of the various home care services, as well as the integration of home care with primary care and hospital care. We will link up home care providers with the GPs, polyclinics and the hospitals, so that there will be less hassle as patients move from one care setting to another. Without coordination and integration, the patients and their families are often at a loss as to how to access the relevant services.  The objective is to care and support the elderly with more complex care needs, so that they can stay at home for as long as possible.  We have begun discussion with the Home Nursing Foundation on this idea as we think that it can play an important role in the transformation of the home healthcare sector.  

 

     Finally, we need to ensure that caregivers are well trained to cope with the physical and socio-emotional needs of the elderly. We provide a Caregiver Training Grant to help caregivers participate in such training programmes. In addition, we are currently studying the need to provide structured skills training for foreign domestic workers as they often are critical members of the caregiver team.

 

     Home care is a focus area of MOH.  There is much that we need to do to beef it up.  Our population is still young, but we will have to start to put the various pieces in place to prepare for a more elderly population in the future.

     19.   Mdm Halimah Yacob asked the Minister for Health (a) if he will provide an update on the state of palliative care in Singapore and whether it is now better integrated across our healthcare system; and (b) whether there are enough trained healthcare professionals to provide effective palliative care.

We will recruit and train more.  We must also leverage on the large number of family physicians out there.  We will help them upgrade their skills in palliative care approaches to enable their terminally ill patients to receive good care towards the end of life. For work done in 2007, 311,000 low-wage workers benefited from Workfare totalling $305 million. This works out to an average of $982 per worker. For work done in 2008, so far 328,000 low-wage workers have received Workfare benefits totalling $386 million, including $55 million in the Workfare Special Payment announced as part of this year’s Resilience Package. This works out to an average of $1,176 per worker.

For example, the CPF Board has identified certain industries as being more prone to non-contribution, and has proactively conducted audit inspections. Between January 2007 and January 2009, these audits have led to more than 57,000 informal workers being converted to formal employment, enabling them to receive CPF contributions regularly. About 10,000 of these employees meet the conditions for Workfare, and have since received Workfare benefits.

     The Workfare scheme has also been designed such that the combined Workfare payment and income is always higher, the more the worker earns. For example, a 65 year-old worker who earns $1,000 a month will have a total average income of $1,200 per month after adding Workfare. If he earns $200 a month in overtime, his Workfare will fall to $120 per month, but his total monthly income still goes up to $1,320. If he has overtime of $600, he will not get any Workfare, but his income of $1,600 will still be higher than earning $1,200 with overtime and Workfare, and $1,000 with no overtime but with Workfare.

TRANSPORT OPERATORS

     22.   Dr Lim Wee Kiak   asked the Minister for Transport with the introduction of shorter waiting times for bus services during peak hours (a) how will the Ministry ensure that transport operators comply with the new timetable; (b) how often will the Ministry be making spot checks to ensure compliance with the new Quality of Service standards; and (c) how many infringements were there in the past 12 months based on the previous Quality of Service standards. 

     Mr Raymond Lim Siang Keat:

     The Public Transport Council (PTC) has tightened the Quality of Service (QoS) standards for basic bus services, effective from 1st August 2009.  Eighty percent of bus services will now have to leave the bus interchanges and terminals every 10 minutes or less during weekday peak periods, from the previous 15 minutes. For feeder services, 90% of feeder services now have to do so at 10 minutes or less, up from the previous 85%. With buses leaving the bus interchanges and terminals at more frequent intervals, commuters can generally expect shorter waiting times.

 

     The PTC monitors and assesses the bus operators' compliance with all QoS standards.  The actual performance of bus services are continuously tracked by the bus operators' computerised fleet operation and management systems.  Based on these databases, performance reports of all bus services are submitted to the PTC every month, and the PTC will assess the operators’ compliance with QoS standards.

 

     To ensure that these performance reports are accurate and complete, the PTC regularly audits the operators' reporting processes and systems. The last check was conducted in August 2008 and the PTC was satisfied that all was in order. The PTC is currently conducting another round of checks on the operators' systems. 

 

     But that is not all.  The PTC conducts an additional layer of checks to ascertain that the performance data actually match commuters' experience on the ground.  The PTC conducts multiple on-site audits or spot checks every month.  If any service lapse is identified, operators are asked to account for and, more importantly, take immediate action to rectify them, even before the PTC announces the results of its six-monthly review of the operators' performance against the QoS standards in April and October every year.

These were on the standards of adherence to scheduled headways and maximum passenger loading, and resulted in the PTC penalising SBS Transit and SMRT Buses $4,500 and $100 respectively.  This was an improvement over the previous six-monthly review, where there were 58 instances of non-compliance and they were fined $9,300 and $1,000 respectively. FOREIGN WORKERS
(Health screening parameters)

     24.   Dr Lam Pin Min asked the Minister for Health (a) what is the current health screening parameters for foreign workers coming to work in Singapore; and (b) whether there is a need for review to make them more stringent in view of the many reports of imported diseases such as tuberculosis, malaria, Chikungunya and other infectious diseases. 

     Mr Khaw Boon Wan:

     Foreigners coming to work in Singapore are required to have a medical examination to assess their health and fitness status.  As part of this medical examination, they are screened for four infectious diseases, namely, tuberculosis (TB), malaria, human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) and syphilis.

 

     Those who are found to have malaria and syphilis will be given the appropriate treatment.  However, those who have HIV infection or active TB are generally not allowed to work in Singapore.

 

     We continually review the screening parameters and put in additional measures as necessary.

 

     For example, last year, we included an additional requirement for foreign domestic workers with scarring on their chest X-ray to undergo further evaluation for active TB disease. Scarring indicates past infection with TB, and those with scarring are at a higher risk of developing active TB disease. We have put in this additional precaution for foreign domestic workers as they work in families which may have young children or elderly people, who are more vulnerable.

 

     Screening for malaria is currently carried out using the peripheral blood film test. This test is most useful when the patient has fever, and is less effective for screening purposes in asymptomatic individuals. We are currently reviewing this screening programme as well as increasing awareness and enhancing early detection of cases.

 

     The disease with the highest number of imported cases last year was Chikungunya. However, the majority of the cases were imported by Singapore residents. Foreign workers accounted for only 15% of the imported cases.

 

     Chikungunya fever is a viral disease transmitted by the bite of infected Aedes mosquitoes. As with malaria, the key to controlling Chikungunya is targeted control of the mosquito vector.
